questions.question: I couldn't answer ............................... questions.
questions.description: Use many with a plural noun use every with a singular noun.

questions.question: I haven't got ............................. money.
questions.description: Much and any are possible here with somewhat different meanings. Money is uncountable so it cannot be used with many.

questions.question: She has so ............................... wealth.
questions.description: Wealth is uncountable use much with it.

questions.question: I don't have ............................... interest in politics.
questions.description: Many is not an adverb. It cannot modify an adjective. Some is used in affirmative clauses.

questions.question: Milk does not provide as .............................. nutrition as curd.
questions.description: Nutrition is an uncountable noun. Use much with it.

questions.question: I did ............................ work in ............................ time today.
questions.description: Less is the comparative form of little.

questions.question: You hardly eat ..................................
questions.description: Hardly is a negative word. You hardly eat anything means the same as you eat nothing.

questions.question: Although I didn't know ............................. at the party, I had a good time.
You have ................................ problems than me.
questions.description: Use a comparative adjective before than. Fewer is the comparative form of few. It is used with plural nouns.

questions.question: I have got .............................. water if you are thirsty.
questions.description: Little means hardly any water. A little indicates a small quantity.
